column3: Samogitian: Klaipieda) is a city in Lithuania on the Baltic Sea coast. It is the third largest city in Lithuania and the capital of Klaipėda County.

column1: The city has a complex recorded history
column2: partially due to the combined regional importance of the usually ice-free Port of Klaipėda at the mouth of the Akmena-Danė River. It was controlled by successive German states until the 1919 Treaty of Versailles. As a result of the 1923 Klaipėda Revolt it was annexed by Lithuania and has remained with Lithuania to this day
column3: except between 1939 and 1945 when it returned to Germany following the 1939 German ultimatum to Lithuania and Molotov–Ribbentrop Pact (between Germany and the Soviet Union).

column9: 311 permanent inhabitants (as of 2019) in Klaipėda city and Klaipėda district municipalities combined. Popular seaside resorts found close to Klaipėda are Nida to the south on the Curonian Spit and Palanga to the north.

column1: The Teutonic Knights built a castle in the *Pilsāts Land of the Curonians and named it Memelburg; later the name was shortened to Memel. From 1252 to 1923 and from 1939 to 1945
column2: the town and city were officially named Memel. Between 1923 and 1939
column3: both names were in official use; since 1945 the Lithuanian name of Klaipėda has been used.

column1: The names Memelburg and Memel are found in most written sources from the 13th century onwards
column2: while Klaipėda is found in Lithuania-related sources since the 15th century. The first time the city was mentioned as Caloypede in the letter of Vytautas in 1413
column3: for the second time in the negotiation documents of 1420 as Klawppeda
column4: and for the third time in the Treaty of Melno of 1422 as Cleupeda. According to Samogitian folk etymology
column5: the name Klaipėda refers to the boggy terrain of the town (klaidyti=obstruct and pėda=foot). Most likely the name is of Curonian origin and means "even ground": "klais/klait" (flat
column6: open
column9: as a reference to relatively flat terrain of the original settlement's surroundings.

column1: The lower reaches of the Neman River were named either *Mēmele or *Mēmela by Scalovians and local Curonian inhabitants. In the Latvian Curonian language it means mute
column5: as a reference to peaceful flow of the Neman River. This name was adopted by speakers of German and also chosen for the new city founded further away at the lagoon.

column1: The coat of arms of Klaipėda is also used as coat of arms of Klaipėda city municipality. The modern version was created by the designer Kęstutis Mickevičius. The modern coat of arms was created by restoring old seals of the Memel city (analogous with those used in the years 1446
column2: 1605 and 1618). It was affirmed on 1 July 1992.

column1: A settlement of Baltic tribes in the territory of the present-day city is said to have existed in the region as early as the 7th century.
In the 1240s the Pope offered King Håkon IV of Norway the opportunity to conquer the peninsula of Sambia. However
column2: following the personal acceptance of Christianity by Grand Duke Mindaugas of Lithuania
column3: the Teutonic Knights and a group of crusaders from Lübeck moved into Sambia
column4: founding unopposed a fort in 1252 recorded as Memele castrum (or Memelburg
column5: "Memel Castle"). The fort's construction was completed in 1253 and Memel was garrisoned with troops of the Teutonic Order
column6: administered by Deutschmeister Eberhard von Seyne. Documents for its foundation were signed by Eberhard and Bishop Heinrich von Lützelburg of Courland on 29 July 1252 and 1 August 1252.

column1: Master Conrad von Thierberg used the fortress as a base for further campaigns along the Neman River and against Samogitia. Memel was unsuccessfully besieged by Sambians in 1255
column2: and the scattered Sambians submitted by 1259. Memel was colonized by settlers from Holstein
column4: hence Memel also being known at the time as Neu-Dortmund
column5: or "New Dortmund". It became the main town of the Diocese of Curonia
column6: with a cathedral and at least two parochial churches
column7: but the development of the castle became the dominant priority. According to different sources
column8: Memel received Lübeck city rights in 1254 or 1258.

column1: In the spring and summer of 1323
column2: a Lithuanian army led by Gediminas came up the Neman and laid siege to the castle of Memel after conquering the town
column4: forcing the Order to sue for a truce in October. During the planning of a campaign against Samogitia
column5: Memel's garrison of the Teutonic Order's Livonian branch was replaced with knights from the Prussian branch in 1328. Threats and attacks by Lithuanians greatly thwarted the town's development; the town and the castle were both sacked by Lithuanian tribes in 1379
column6: while Samogitians attacked 800 workers rebuilding Memel in 1389.

column1: The Treaty of Melno in 1422 stabilized the border between the Teutonic Order and the Grand Duchy of Lithuania for the next 501 years. The rebuilt town received Kulm law city rights in 1475. Memel remained part of what became Prussia and Germany; the border to Lithuania remained unchanged until 1919. It was one of the longest-lasting borders in Europe
column2: and is referred to in the now-unsung first verse of the German national anthem
column3: which describes borders of German-speaking lands: Von der Maas bis an die Memel
column4: referring to the Meuse river in the West and Neman river in the East.

column1: Against the wishes of its governor and commander
column3: Memel adopted Lutheranism after the conversion of Hohenzollern Margrave of Brandenburg Albert of Prussia and the creation of the Duchy of Prussia as a fief of the Crown of the Kingdom of Poland in 1525. It was the onset of a long period of prosperity for the city and port. It served as a port for neighbouring Lithuania
column4: benefiting from its location near the mouth of the Neman
column5: with wheat as a profitable export. The Duchy of Prussia was inherited by a relative
column6: John Sigismund
column7: the Hohenzollern prince-electors of the March of Brandenburg in 1618. Brandenburg-Prussia began active participation in regional policy
column8: which affected the development of Memel. From 1629–1635
column9: the town was occupied by Sweden over several periods during the Polish-Swedish War of 1625–1629 and the Thirty Years' War.

column1: After the Treaty of Königsberg in 1656 during the Northern Wars
column2: Elector Frederick William opened Memel's harbor to Sweden
column3: with whom the harbor's revenue was divided. Prussian independence from Poland and Sweden was affirmed in the Treaty of Oliva in 1660.

column1: The construction of a defence system around the entire town
column3: noticeably changed its status and prospects. In November 1678 a small Swedish army invaded Prussian territory
column4: but was unable to capture the fortress of Memel.

column1: By the beginning of the 18th century
column2: Memel was one of the strongest fortresses (Memelfestung) in Prussia
column3: and the town became part of the Kingdom of Prussia in 1701. Despite its fortifications
column4: it was captured by Russian troops during the Seven Years' War in 1757. Consequently
column5: from 1757–1762 the town
column6: along with the rest of eastern Prussia
column7: was dependent on the Russian Empire. After this war ended
column8: the maintenance of the fortress was neglected

column1: Memel became part of the province of East Prussia within the Kingdom of Prussia in 1773. In the second half of the 18th century Memel's lax customs and Riga's high duties enticed English traders
column2: who established the first industrial sawmills in the town. In 1784
column4: 500 of which were English. (In 1900 there was still an active English church in Memel
column5: as well as a "British Hotel"). The specialisation in wood manufacturing guaranteed Memel's merchants income and stability for more than a hundred years. During this era it also normalised its trade relations with Königsberg; regional instability had degraded relations since the 16th century.

column1: Memel prospered during the second half of the 18th century by exporting timber to Great Britain for use by the Royal Navy. In 1792
column2: 756 British ships visited the town to transport lumber from the Lithuanian forests near Memel. In 1800 its imports consisted chiefly of salt
column5: were corn
column6: hemp
column10: timber. The 1815 Encyclopædia Britannica stated that Memel was "provided with the finest harbour in the Baltic".

column2: Memel became the temporary capital of the Kingdom of Prussia. Between 1807 and 1808
column3: the town was the residence of King Frederick William III
column5: his court
column6: and the government. On 9 October 1807 the king signed a document in Memel
column8: which abolished serfdom in Prussia. It originated the reforms of Karl Freiherr vom und zum Stein and Karl August von Hardenberg. The land around Memel suffered major economic setbacks under Napoleon Bonaparte's Continental System. During Napoleon's retreat from Moscow after the failed invasion of Russia in 1812
column9: General Yorck refused Marshal MacDonald's orders to fortify Memel at Prussia's expense.

column1: After the unification of Germany into the German Empire in 1871
column2: Memel had the distinction of being Germany's northernmost city.

column1: The development of the town in the 19th century was influenced by the industrial revolution in Prussia and the attendant processes of urbanisation. Even though the population of Memel increased fourfold during the 19th century
column4: its pace of development lagged in comparison. The reasons for this were mostly political. Memel was the northernmost and easternmost city in Germany
column5: and although the government was engaged in a very costly tree-planting exercise to stabilise the sand-dunes on the Curonian Spit
column6: most of the financial infusions in the province of East Prussia were concentrated in Königsberg
column7: the capital of the province. Some notable instances of the German infrastructure investments in the area included sandbar blasting and a new ship canal between Pillau and Königsberg
column8: which enabled vessels of up to 6.5 m draughts to moor alongside the city
column9: at a cost of 13 million marks.

column1: Owing to the absence of heavy industry in the 1870s and 1880s
column3: although wood manufacturing persisted as the main industry. It remained the central point of the Baltic timber-trade. A British Consul was located in the town in 1800; in 1900 a British Vice-Consul was recorded there
column4: as well as a Lloyd's Agent.

column1: By 1900 steamer services had been established between Memel and Cranz (on the southern end of the Curonian Spit)
column2: and also between Memel and Tilsit. A main-line railway was built from Insterburg
column3: the main East Prussian railway junction
column5: the Prussian frontier station. The Memel line also ran from Insterburg via Tilsit
column6: where a further direct line connected with Königsberg
column7: that crossed the 4 kilometres (2 miles) wide Memel River Valley over three bridges before its arrival in Memel.

column1: During the second half of the 19th century
column2: Memel was a center for the publication of books printed in the Lithuanian language using a Latin-script alphabet – these publications were prohibited in the nearby Russian Empire of which Lithuania was a province. The books were then smuggled over the Lithuanian border.

column1: The German 1910 census lists the Memel Territory population as 149
column4: 345 declared Lithuanian to be their first language. The Germans greatly predominated in the town and port of Memel as well as in other nearby villages; the Lithuanian population was predominant in the area's rural districts.

column1: Under the Treaty of Versailles after World War I
column2: Klaipėda and the surrounding Klaipėda Region (Memel Territory) were detached from Germany and made a protectorate of the Entente States. The French became provisional administrators of the region until a more permanent solution could be worked out. Both Lithuania and Poland campaigned for their rights in the region. However
column3: it seemed that the region would become a free city
column4: similar to the Free City of Danzig. Not waiting for an unfavorable decision
column5: the Lithuanians decided to stage the Klaipėda Revolt
column6: take the region by force
column7: and present the Entente with a fait accompli. The revolt was carried out in January 1923 while western Europe was distracted by the occupation of the Ruhr. The Germans tacitly supported the action
column8: while the French offered only limited resistance. The League of Nations protested the revolt
column9: but accepted the transfer in February 1923. The formal Klaipėda Convention was signed in Paris on 8 May 1924
column10: securing extensive autonomy for the region.The annexation of the city had enormous consequences for the Lithuanian economy and foreign relations. The region subsequently accounted for up to 30% of the Lithuania's entire production. Between 70% and 80% of foreign trade passed through Klaipėda. The region
column11: which represented only about 5% of Lithuania's territory
column12: contained a third of its industry. Weimar Germany
column14: maintained normal relations with Lithuania. However
column15: Nazi Germany desired to reacquire the region and tensions rose. Pro-German parties won clear supermajorities in all elections to the Klaipėda Parliament
column16: which often clashed with the Lithuanian-appointed Klaipėda Directorate. Lithuanian efforts to "re-Lithuanize" Prussian Lithuanians by promoting Lithuanian language
column18: education were often met with resistance from the locals. In 1932
column19: a conflict between the Parliament and the Directorate had to be resolved by the Permanent Court of International Justice. In 1934–1935
column20: the Lithuanians attempted to combat increasing Nazi influence in the region by arresting and prosecuting over 120 Nazi activists for the alleged plot to organize an anti-Lithuanian rebellion. Despite rather harsh sentences
column21: the defendants in the so-called Neumann–Sass case were soon released under pressure from Nazi Germany. The extensive autonomy guaranteed by the Klaipėda Convention prevented Lithuania from blocking the growing pro-German attitudes in the region.

column1: As tensions in pre-war Europe continued to grow
column2: it was expected that Germany would make a move against Lithuania to reacquire the region. German Foreign Minister Joachim von Ribbentrop delivered an ultimatum to the Lithuanian Foreign Minister on 20 March 1939
column3: demanding the surrender of Klaipėda. Lithuania
column4: unable to secure international support for its cause
column5: submitted to the ultimatum and
column6: in exchange for the right to use the new harbour facilities as a Free Port
column7: ceded the disputed region to Germany in the late evening of 22 March 1939. Adolf Hitler visited the harbour and delivered a speech to the city residents. This was Hitler's last territorial acquisition before World War II.

column4: the inhabitants fled as the fighting drew nearer. The nearly empty city was captured by the Soviet Red Army on 28 January 1945 with only about 50 remaining people. After the war the Memel Territory was incorporated into the Lithuanian SSR
column5: marking the start of a new epoch in the history of the city
column6: and the end of the city's belonging to the German speaking lands.

Klaipėda city municipality council is the governing body of the Klaipėda city municipality. It is responsible for municipal laws. The council is composed of 31 members (30 councillors and a mayor) directly elected for four-year terms.
The council is the member of the Association of Local Authorities in Lithuania.
Klaipėda's climate is humid continental (Köppen Dfb) but quite close to being oceanic (Köppen Cfb). In July and August
column4: and low temperatures average 14 °C (57 °F). The highest official temperature ever recorded was 36.6 °C (97.9 °F) in August 2014. In January and February
column5: the coldest season
column6: high temperatures average 0 °C (32 °F) with low temperatures averaging −5 °C (23 °F). The coldest temperature ever recorded in Klaipėda is −33.4 °C (−28.1 °F) in February 1956.

column1: The wettest month is November with a mean total precipitation 90 mm (3.5 inches). August through November is the wettest season because of the warmth of the Baltic sea in relation to the continent and the westerly winds. The driest month is February averaging 31 mm (1.2 in) of total precipitation. Spring is not particularly wet.
Klaipėda is a windy city with many stormy days per year. In autumn and winter
column2: gales are not unusual. Sea breezes are common from April to September. Snow can fall from October to April and a phenomenon resembling lake-effect snow is frequent. Severe snowstorms can paralyze the city in winter.

column1: Klaipėda has unsettled weather all year round. Some winters can be cold and snowy
column5: and rainy
column6: similar to the weather in Glasgow. August 2005 was very rainy
column7: while August 2002 barely had any precipitation at all.

column1: The Port of Klaipėda is the principal ice-free port on the eastern coast of the Baltic Sea. It is the most important Lithuanian transportation hub
column3: land and railway routes from East to West. Klaipėda is a multipurpose
column5: deep-water port. Nineteen big stevedoring companies
column6: ship-repair and shipbuilding yards operate within the port and all marine business and cargo handling services are rendered.

column1: The annual port cargo handling capacity is up to 40 Mt. The port operates 24 hours a day
The tallest building in Klaipėda is 34-storey Pilsotas.
Klaipėda railway station (Lithuanian: Klaipėdos geležinkelio stotis) is located at Priestočio g. 1
Klaipėda railway station consists of two buildings. The old building
column2: made of yellow bricks and reflecting features of Classicism architecture was built in 1881. Currently
column3: the building hosts various small businesses. The railway station is located in the new building

column1: The railway network of then Prussia reached Klaipėda in 1878. Initially merely used for lumber and fish freight on Klaipėda–Šilutė
column3: the railway grid network of Lithuania Minor received a major boost after Klaipėda uprising and annexation of the region by Lithuania in 1923.

column1: As of 2017 Lithuanian Railways were operating two routes from Klaipėda railway station. 4 daily trains on route Klaipėda - Vilnius and 2 daily trains on the Klaipėda–Radviliškis routes. Train tickets could be obtained at the station
column2: online at www.traukiniobilietas.lt or with a surcharge - on board the trains.

column1: The railway station is served by the following buses of Klaipėda city passenger transport:
No. 9 south of the city - city hospital (via Central Klaipėda Terminal)
No. 6 south of the city - Melnragė district (Melnragė beaches)
No. 8 south of city - bus station (through Old town)
No. 15 south of the city - city hospital
No. 100 bus station - Palanga International Airport (PLQ)
Domestic and international commercial scheduled airline services are provided by Palanga International Airport. The airport is connected with Klaipėda by a city bus.
Klaipėda is also serviced by a small
column2: privately run aerodrome with a focus on sports aviation and charter services.

column1: Klaipėda is located next to Curonian Spit and a small part of the peninsula (Smiltynė) is within Klaipėda. People can reach the peninsula by ferry using one of the two terminals.
The Old ferry terminal (Danės st. 1) - ferry from city center for passengers traveling on foot or with bikes;
The New ferry terminal (Nemuno st. 8) - ferry for people with motorized vehicles.
From Klaipėda there are three ferry lines and two ferry companies: DFDS Seaways and TT-Line.
DFDS operates ferries to Kiel (Germany) and Karlshamn (Sweden). Ferries depart from the Central Klaipėda Terminal (CKT). TT-Line ferries are going to Trelleborg (Sweden).
Klaipėda's bus public transportation is based on geographical peculiarities. It is arranged by the north-south axis
column2: based on three parallel principal streets
column3: running along the coast of Curonian Lagoon and thus making the grid logical and comfortable for commuting.It is possible to buy an electronic card in shops and newspaper stands (kiosks) and top it up with an appropriate amount of money. Public transport is organized
column4: supervised and coordinated by Klaipėda city passenger transport.

column1: Buses to other cities and towns depart from Klaipėda bus station (Butkų Juzės g. 9).
Buses to Curonian Spit villages Nida and Juodkrantė depart from a bus stop in Smiltynė (next to the Old ferry terminal).

Trams in Klaipėda functioned in 1904—1934 and 1950—1967. It was one only tram transport in the last years of first independent Lithuania and in Soviet Lithuania and one only electric tram ever in country. It was interurban transport serving not Klaipėda only. It was operated by Memeler Kleinbahn AG company.

Tram system had two lines with 12 km of tracks and 17 tramcars. First line was from old city (lighthouse and Strandvilla restaurant) through center and northern suburbs Royal (Didžioji) Vitė and Bomelio Vitė localities to sea beaches and resort Melnragė. Second line was from old city through industrial suburb Royal Smeltė to south to Wilhelm channel and Wooden bay. Lines had connection near Stock exchange in center of city. Branch connected the center with railway station through Liepaja (now Manto) Street and Liepaja (now Lietuvninku) Square. Other branch passed near Winter port through Vite locality. In 1950—1967 tram run functioned in line to Smeltė only. Tram lines used for delivery of goods from railway and port also. Tram degradated and closed due to wear and tear and lack of funds for its renewal and development. Now city's authorities plans to revive tram and inculdes them in urban plan-general. Line will be interurban again and plans to connect Klaipėda with Šventoji through airport and Palanga. In 2017 feasibility study began for first tram line on Herkus Manto and Taikos streets

Klaipėda's Old Town is notable among other towns in Lithuania for its abundance of German and Scandinavian architecture. Klaipėda's Old Town is unique with its fachwerk architectural style and the planned street structure
column2: which is uncharacteristic to any other old town in Lithuania. Its streets are geometrically configured very correctly
column3: and the angle of intersection is always straight.
